
Demographics of the Western Balkans
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to navigationJump to search

This article may be too long to read and navigate comfortably. Please consider splitting content into sub-articles, condensing it, or adding subheadings. (March 2020)
See also: Demographics of Albania, Demographics of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Demographics of Croatia, Demographics of Kosovo, Demographics of Montenegro, Demographics of North Macedonia, Demographics of Serbia, and Demographics of Slovenia
Demographics of the Western Balkans is article about the demographic features of the population of the Western Balkans, including average population, live births, deaths, natural change, crude rate (birth, death and natural change) per 1000 people, general, specific and total fertility rates, female fertile population (15-49 years), marriages, divorces and other aspects of the population. "Western Balkans" is a political neologism coined to refer to Albania and the territory of the former Yugoslavia (Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Kosovo, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia and Slovenia), since the early 1990s. The region of the Western Balkans, a coinage exclusively used in Pan-European parlance, roughly corresponds to the Dinaric Alps territory.

Western Balkans vital statistics
[1][2]

Vital statistics by country
Albania
[3][4][5][6]

1998	1,982,603	17,856	19,039	-1,183	9.0	9.6	-0.6	1.23	516,296
1999	1,985,557	17,533	18,885	-1,352	8.8	9.5	-0.7	1.21	516,261
2000	1,990,272	18,180	18,588	-408	9.1	9.3	-0.2	1.26	515,258
2001	1,992,035	17,477	18,508	-1,031	8.8	9.3	-0.5	1.21	512,358
2002	1,995,718	17,501	18,701	-1,200	8.8	9.4	-0.6	1.21	510,692
2003	1,996,773	17,321	19,451	-2,130	8.7	9.7	-1.1	1.21	507,713
2004	1,997,004	17,961	18,523	-562	9.0	9.3	-0.3	1.25	504,530
2005	2,001,114	18,157	18,825	-668	9.1	9.4	-0.3	1.26	500,449
2006	2,008,516	18,932	18,180	752	9.4	9.1	0.4	1.32	496,853
2007	2,019,406	19,823	18,584	1,239	9.8	9.2	0.6	1.39	491,536
2008	2,022,629	21,817	18,308	3,509	10.8	9.1	1.7	1.54	486,506
2009	2,042,335	21,856	18,750	3,106	10.7	9.2	1.5	1.54	483,680
2010	2,049,261	22,343	18,609	3,734	10.9	9.1	1.8	1.58	479,815
2011	2,052,496	21,947	18,699	3,248	10.7	9.1	1.6	1.57	474,646
2012	2,056,262	21,938	19,257	2,681	10.7	9.4	1.3	1.59	469,442
2013	2,059,114	21,111	19,334	1,777	10.3	9.4	0.9	1.55	463,138
2014	2,061,623	21,165	18,886	2,279	10.3	9.2	1.1	1.58	456,811
2015	2,063,077	20,641	19,834	807	10.0	9.6	0.4	1.58	450,224
2016	2,064,241	20,345	19,689	656	9.9	9.5	0.3	1.59	443,390
2017	2,066,161	20,241	20,509	-268	9.8	9.9	-0.1	1.62	436,478
2018 [67]	2,070,050	19,585	20,485	-900	9.5	9.9	-0.4	1.61	430,225
2019	2,089,310								428,255
Average population	Live births	Deaths	Natural change	Crude birth rate (per 1000)	Crude death rate (per 1000)	Natural change (per 1000)	Total fertility rate	Female fertile population (15-49 years)
Total 1950-2018		1,744,229	1,243,263	500,966	942.1	671.5	270.6
Average 1950-2018	1,851,471	25,279	18,018	7,260	13.7	9.7	3.9	1.86	462,824

Current vital statistics
[68]

Births

from January - September 2018 = 14,863
from January - September 2019 = 14,502
Difference between number of births in 2018 and 2019 (January - September) = Decrease -361 (-2.43%)
Deaths

from January - September 2018 = 15,279
from January - September 2019 = 15,431
Difference between number of deaths in 2018 and 2019 (January - September) = Negative increase +152 (+0.99%)
Natural increase

from January - September 2018 = -416
from January - September 2019 = -929
Difference between natural increase in 2018 and 2019 (January - September) = Decrease -513
